children.subject: <md>Can't comment on 105. 16B sort of speed runs half of the 120 content in its second and third modules. So people who have taken 16B (tbh a vast majority of students in 120) will have some prior exposure and context to 120 material. However, 120 operates at a very reasonable pace and teaches everything from the ground up, so you're not really going to suffer so much for not having taken 16B. Everyone else may just pick up concepts faster from having seen things before. Relevant parts of 16B include filters, transfer functions, diff eq, controls, DFT, discretization, interpolation.</md>

Agreed with what Jay has said about 120 introducing concepts from the ground up. For context, my iteration of 16B did not cover the DFT, and I would say it has not affected how prepared I have felt for the course.

For 105, unless you have prior experience with the relevant concepts or are confident in your ability to effectively self-study them, I would probably not recommend taking it concurrently with 16B. These topics would mainly be frequency response, bode plots, transfer functions, complex impedance, RC/RLC circuits, and CMOS logic. Even though these concepts show up relatively early in 16B as well, and may be reviewed in 105 as well (depending on the professor), I think building the intuition behind how circuits work with AC signals usually takes some practice and time. 

Other concepts that are useful for 105 are introduced in 16A, so you would be fine on that front: ideal op-amps and common topologies (inverting amplifier, non-inverting amplifier, etc.), negative feedback, Thevenin equivalents.

history.content: Is it doable to do EE 120 or EE 105 concurrently with EECS 16B? Or rather, how disadvantaged would I be in taking 16b along with either 120 or 105? Also, which topics in 16B would be directly relevant to 120 or 105 (for self-studying ahead of time)?
history.subject: EE 120 or 105 with EECS 16B
